sub_topic: Population growth models using differential equations
message_1: A certain city has a population of 1 million people, and it is growing at a rate proportional to the number of people present. If the current growth rate is 2% per year, what will the population of the city be in 10 years?
message_2:
To find the population of the city in 10 years, we can use the formula for exponential growth:

P(t) = P0 * (1 + r)^t

where P(t) is the population at time t, P0 is the initial population, r is the growth rate, and t is the number of years.

In this case, P0 = 1,000,000, r = 0.02 (2% as a decimal), and t = 10.

P(10) = 1,000,000 * (1 + 0.02)^10
P(10) = 1,000,000 * (1.02)^10
P(10) ≈ 1,000,000 * 1.218994
P(10) ≈ 1,218,994

So, the population of the city in 10 years will be approximately 1,218,994 people.
